JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MARYLAND.JANUARY 19, 1968

SNCC Seeki g Control
Of City Scboo! System
By STEVE SHRIVER
The first major goal of the newly-established Baltimore SNCC will
be the control of the public school
system by the black people of
Baltimore.
"Black children make up 70
per cent of the school population
of Baltimore," said Baltimore Field
Secretary Robert Moore,"but they
have always gotten the rotten end
of the deal. The whites of this city
have completely forfeited any right
to make decisions in this area."
SNCC has joined a coalition of
eight other Human Rights groups,
among them CORE, U-JOIN and
the Interdenominational Ministerial Alliance, to press the attack on
the school system. The groups immediate demands are the installation of six "Afro-Americans" on
the Baltimore School Board and
the appointment of a black Superintendent of Schools. The group
has recommended John Hopkins,
former assistant to the late School
Superintendent Lawrence Paquin
who is in charge of the Community School Program, for the
position.
Coalition
SNCC has presented the coalition with its three-point program.
It calls for instruction in AfroAmerican History and Swahili, and
for the control of local schools by
the neighborhood..
"Black people are in a better
position to understand the needs
of black children than are white
people," said Mr. Moore. He also
indicated that the "general feeling"
of the coalition was favorable to
.the SNCC program.
In a corollary program, Mr.
Moore said that SNCC would work
to establish Black Student Unions
in the Junior and Senior High
Schools. He said that high school
students had been found to be
"very aware of what was happening." He said that nine high school
rebellions had taken place this fall.
He also indicated that the Unions
would include programs of Black
Draft Resistance.
Assist Blacks
Moore said that SNCC would
encourage and assist students at
black colleges to form student

unions tO fight for student-faculty
control and to bring the "culture
and heritage of the Afro- American
to the campus." In line with this,
he said SNCC would seek to create
ties between these colleges potential sources of leadership and the
black community.
"Despite their responsibility to
relate to it," he added,"most students look down on the black community." He charged that college
administrations fostered this outlook while attempting to serve
White America.
Mr. Moore called on black students at Hopkins to form a Black
Student Union, and also stated
that the SNCC office would welcome student assistance as well as
offer help to sympathetic groups.
SNCC is sharing its office with
U-JOIN and the Mothers Rescuers
from Poverty, a welfare group at
432 East North Avenue.The office
will be staffed six days a week
from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The three
groups are hoping to put out a

SC Revamps Bill of Rights
The Student Council threw out
the term "Bill of Rights" and returned the proposal to its central
committee to be redrafted as a
"Statement of Student Rights and
Responsibilities."
Discussion on the bill began
with Manuel Rodriguez, who questioned the need for any statement,
such as the Council' was preparing.
The council had to be sure, he
warned, that such a statement was
the best way to achieve student
goals.
The council reached a consensus that the "Bill of Rights" was
too agressive a term, carrying with
it some undesirable connotations.
A motion proposed by Russ Passarella was adopted by the council
as the major guiding principle of
the rights Statement: "The students of the Johns Hopkins University have the right to participate
in the formulation of university
policies which directly affect the
student." The vote to accept this
as a major guideline was 12-4.
The Statement has been returned to Committee with high hopes,

as expressed by Ken Bond, who
predicted that the statement
would be a document "second
only to the Constitution of the
United States."
The Central Committee which
originally drafted the statement
will work with the three-man faculty board which was established
last week in council. The latter
board is cOmprised of Mr. Bilgrave,
Dr. Gordon Wolman of Geography and Dr. David Donald of History.
The 'council also passed Jim
Winship's motion to set up three

several janitors, inspected their
fingers, and discovered the telltale

Alf Weinbach, a member of the

Judge Joseph G. Tinnerty of
the Northern Municipal Court convicted Newton and sentenced him
to 90 days in jail. Newton, however, has decided to appeal the
decision, and was released on $500
bail.
The arrest marks a turning point
in the career of the Hopkins police
department and law enforcement
on the campus in general. With
such modern devices as dye, radio
patrol cars and border guard
booths, the campus police are
expected to more effectively curtail crime and thieverey in our
lanes and buildings.
"We have come a long way
since the days of beating the grass,
only ten short years ago," one
officer said. "But we still have a
way to go, I'm afraid."

JOURNAL JOLTED
To the Editors:
Hopkins Alumni Journal
Your recent article about Hopkins undergraduates titled "Yes,
Virginia, There Are Students Who
Don't Protest" tells a great deal
about the campus, and about the
sort of school Hopkins is, It very
clearly points out the isolation of
the University and of its students.
For the "nine diversified Johns
Hopkins students" interviewed
"foreign policy, Vietnam and the
draft" play a very unimportant
part in life. It's very nice not to
have to worry about things like
that. It's nice to have attended a
private school, and even nicer to
have attended "private schools in
Paris and New England." It's nice
to be "surrounded by people like'
me. We're not worried about the
draft because we'll probably
never be drafted. Most of us go
to graduate school." It's nice to
be able to worry about not becoming "a fat and happy businessman". And it's nice to know
that "since we're living in a society of consumer idiots" that
"there are enough of them to
support a few idiots like me."
It's also nice to have enough
money to come to Hopkins.
What's the Journal getting at?
Are these nine randomly picked
students? One of them is Black.
Does that mean that one of every
nine undergraduates is Black? or
one of every twenty? or thirty?
What relation should a university
have to the society that supports
it? What is Hopkins doing to
benefit that society? Should a
university function as a sanctuary
from the draft, as a protection

Correspondence

any real involvement with problems outside the campus?
These are very real problems.
Hopkins must learn that it does
have a role outside the boundaries
of Homewood. We must learn
that the Black slum, the poor,
and Vietnam are very much our
problems. The Applied Physics
designs missile systems. The Hospital does research into biological
warfare. Hopkins makes no more
than token moves to admit Black
undergraduates. Until Hopkins
can recognize its responsibilities
she can expect no more than the
complacency and isolation the
students you have interviewed
have shown.
Sincerely,
Michael D. Ornstein
Department of
Social Relations
BILL BOUNCED
To the Editors:
One would like to think that
the four points from the draft bill
of rights quoted in last Friday's
News-Letter are perhaps not typical of the whole document, although I would not hold out much
hope. Since the bill will undoubtedly be notable more for what it
does not contain than for what it
does, it is perhaps a bit early to
criticize it. However, even .in the
excerpt that appearedin the NewsLetter there are tiems that are not
only useless but positively harmful.
Consider, for example, Point
Four, which concerns the NewsLetter directly: "No student publication shall be subjected to any
form of censorship so long as it

remains within the limits of acceptable community standards"? Would thi!
mean a ban on four-letter words?
Most members of the university
community use four-letter words
in their speech. Would an article
by a member of the NLFSV bc
permitted to appear? Many Hopkins students support a policy
that says that members of the
NLFSV should be killed. The
people who are to define "acceptable community standards"
are faced with a difficult task
indeed.
But more important than the
difficulty of defining these standards are the insidious implications of even trying. The editors
of the News-Letter are entrusted
with an important job. They
should also be trusted to use their
own judgment when it comes to
deciding what to print without
having to worry about "acceptable community standards," real
or imagined. An important function of the student - - or any - press can be to try to change
these standards. If a student publication is supposed to conform
to "acceptable community standards", then it can never experiment, never try to educate its
readers, never comment on anything more than the trivial.
Mr. Resnik (who has obviously either never read the Daily
News or never read the NewsLetter) is not the first person to
criticize a student newspaper for
being one-sided. Keeping student
council members and university
administrators satisfied that the
funds that go to the student paper are money well-spent is a
ficult problem and one for which

S.A. Plans Extension of Tutorial Services
More Tutors. New Location.
Draft Program Added
The Student Association is planning to expand its tutorial services
and to initiate a program concerning the draft next semester.
The Tutoring Program, under
the direction of Steve Wilmore
and Marc Canfield, assistants to
Dr. Chester Wickwire, the executive director of the SA, presently
concentrates on grade school
children.
The tutoring services are offered at locations on George Street
in west Baltimore and Monument
Street in east Baltimore.
Canfield intends to expand the
services to include students of
junior high school. He also hopes
to extend the services to a new
location, in the area of North and
Pennsylvania Avenues.
More Tutors
Canfield hopes to be able to
recruit more tutors in order to be
able to expand- the services easily.
He cited the "enthusiasm" of the
present tutors as a factor which led
him to believe that expansion
would be possible.
The SA will hold a trainInsa_

workshop for newly recruited tutors on February 10, in Levering
Hall, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.
The SA presently has Hopkins
students working at the North and
Pennsylvania Avenue locations,
where Canfield hopes to institute
a tutoring services. At this time,
the students work with street
clubs and gangs. Canfield said that
plans to add tutoring services were
"still in the formative stage."

The SA will begin a month long
series on the Selective Service and
the draft next February. Topics
will include conscientious objection, details concerning the present
draft law, draft resistance and a
talk on the constitutionality of
The draft forums will be held
on Tuesdays, at 4 p.m. in Levering
Hall. Details will be announced
after semester break.

share of the responsibility. I tend
to doubt whether there is any
solution that won't lead to somebody's feeling cheated; the student editor's freedom must certainly be respected, but there

COMPUTER CONFUSION
To the Editors:
In reply to Mr. Sakowich's satire in last week's News-Letter, I
can only say that he has missed
the entire significance of the university's gesture. The administration finally does something nice
for its students and what thanks
do they receive? Sarcasm! I am
not saying that there aren't way
to improve this program, but this
is certainly a start. If the administration thinks that all of the
students think the way you do,
they could justifiably terminate
the program.
What you are missing is that
20 — 25% of the students 911this
campus know how to program a
computer, and for them computer time is a very valuable and
unobtainable commodity. And,

for those who lack such training,
it takes only $1.00 to purchase
a manual for BASIC in the bookstore, and a couple of hours of
study can produce results. There
is nothing mystical or magical
about computer programming,
and it's simpler than any foreign
language. .
What freshman chemistry student wouldn't like to have a
computer do his homework for
him? Access to a computer can
also reduce the drudgery of repeated calculations for physics
labs, and computer programming
is an integral part of many advanced sciences. Since about 2/3
of Hopkins students are science
majors, there may be far more
people who are interested in this
program than you indicate.
I can understand an English
major's sarcasm at such a program, but I personally know
several graduate students in such
fields as Semitics, ancient languages, and Education who are
programming the major part of
their Masters or Doctoral theses.
Computer programming is invading other areas as well, for
example teaching, moviemaking,
and even poetry and music. Computers are already capable of
beating beginners at such games
as chess, checkers and bridge.
If, however, you, and the
many others like you, feel that
the computer is alien to you and
has no place in your lives except
in D-level of the library, please
drop your cards in box 2129 and
they will be put to better use
than making paper airplanes or
papering the walls.
Warren Levy '70

The Yearning Years
In retrospect, a college "education" must seem a cruel paradox. If
we have learned anything from four years of lectures, seminars,
exams and papers it is the harsh realization of how much remains
unlearned. A semester of Dante teaches us how inadequate one semester can be. We learn enough to become curious, enough to become
interested, but in the last analysis, not nearly enough. College teases
us but we can't get no satisfaction. It takes us half way there, if that
far.
The pressure to specialize pours salt on the wound. It is as strong
at Hopkins as anywhere, perhaps stronger. The pre-med, with Mitochondria and adenosine triphosphate burdening his mind, has only
vague recollections of Homer and Hegel.The history major associates
chemistry with lysergic acid and spends his waking hours absorbed in
the revisionist theories of the revisionist, who revised the revisionist
interpretation of the origins of the Civil War. The Hopkins student
may gain some expertise in a narrow field of study while in other
disciplines he remains functionally illiterate.
In this sense, the University may be at fault. We are always told
about the virtues of our liberal academic philosophy, struck from
the mold of German universities. Hopkins is, in fact, a ;staunch defender of academic freedom and it is indeed a more desirable educational philosophy than that practiced by a Princeton or Chicago
where rigidity is the by-word. The freedom to structure one's education almost free of insipid requirements should not be taken lightly.
The reality of this liberal philosophy, however, has not created the
"Renaissance man" at Hopkins nor has it created anything more
than an incipient specialist.
The fault does not, however,lie with Lincoln Gordon,or his nine
predecessors,or the faculty,or the student. The roots of the problem
must be traced back to the day one enters public school for the first
time. The tragedy of the Hopkins student is that the liberal, progressive philosophy of his college does not jive with the rigid conservatism that governs the first twelve years of his education. In essence,
a liberal philosophy of higher education assumes that the individual
possesses a high degree of technical knowledge and that a college
should stress development of the analytical powers of reasoning. This
is a false assumption since the products of the public school system
are ill-prepared to cope with anything more provocative than Introductory Chemistry or History.
Consequently, Hopkins and other surveyors of academic freedom
must keep a stiff upper lip and give their entering students cram
courses in the fundamentals of Biology and Sociology. It is not until the third or fourth year that the student is asked to use his mind
and manipulate ideas, but by that time his intellectual curiosity is
worn thin by chemical formulas and historical dates.
The blame, as we said, lies squarely with the American system of
public education. Numerous attempts have been made to reform
"the system" but bureaucratization has rendered them futile. Recently, a committee chaired by McGeorge Bundy of the Ford
Thundation suggested to Mayor Lindsay of New York a sweeping
decentralization of that city's school system. The committee's report
proposed the creation of 30 to 60 largely autonomous school districts with each district run by a local school board. These local
school boards would have the power to hire and fire superintendants
and teachers,determine curricula and make decisions on tenure. As a
a result, the Board of Education would be restricted to the role of an
overseer. But the Bundy Report and any other plan for school decentralization is destined to fail unless basic changes are made in the
classroom.
Psychologists have been saying for years that the youngster is
capable of a much higher level of reasoning and understanding than
both his teachers and parents give him credit. The absudity of a college student clutching a Spanish elements book is a severe indictment of his elementary school years. While he was playing with
blocks and coloring pretty pictures, his mind was capable of a greater challenge-only the challenge never came.
This process of intellectual retardation leads to the great myths
that students acquire in high school. The industrial revolution is
glorified while some of its more iunfortunate creations are totally
ignored. Wars are exciting and colorful, not brutal and unbearable.
There have been some energetic people who tried to fight the
system, but they,like all the utopians before them, suffered ignominious defeat. Jonathan Kozol was kicked out of a Boston school
for reading a Langston Hughes poem to his class and Herbert Kohl's
sixth grade class in Harlem was forced to publish secretly a newspaper which expressed the fears and horrors of the ghetto. The system
had driven them underground.
The system is bureaucratic, insensitive,rigid and worst of all - the
destroyer of people's minds. It is, therefore, the unwanted duty of
institutions like Hopkins to reclaim, and regenerate the once promising intellects of its students. In this process, the tenets of academic freedom are necessarily neglected. This is indeed tragic but
Hopkins will be forced to turn out unsatisfactory products as long
as she is faced with the task of revitalizing the minds of her students.
The cruel paradox of college education will persist until the public
school system with the help of progressive universities turns'inward
and destroys those structures that contribute so heavily to the intellectual retardation of the student.

Lester: Gut Coarse

By MICHAEL G. MICHAELSON
Quietly,suddenly perhaps, with
resignation, John Lennon sits
down in the high thick grass. His
brown eyes open wide and innocent, his jaw drops, he seems tired,
sad,even a little amused. His hands
look a bit greenish, clasped there
over the red gushing mass of blood
that had once been his groin.
"You didn't expect this," he asks
the audience in a bored monotone,
"did you?"
Only we did. Of course we did.
Not because we have seen all the
reviews of How I Won the War
(which of course we have) not because we have seen the Beatle's
battered, bloody body splashed
on the cover of the October Ramparts (which of course we have)
but because director Richard Lester makes us expect it and does
even more. When it does happen,
he makes us believe it too.
Anti-Film Flick
Lester's film is about war and
war stories (war movies, war heroes, war villians). The dualism of
his subject is a product of Lester's
conviction not that war and the
celebration of war are the same,
but that just such a false identity
has been so easy and so comfortable to assume, so dishonest and so
simply, morally wrong. Lester is
Out to crush the myths,"the legacy" as he told an interviewer,"of
twenty years of fiction," and expose the "implausible, illogical,
secret and steel unreality," that is
the final (and paradoxical and
cruel) reality of war.
"It's not very funny, you
know," freckle-faced Lieutenant
Goodbody(Michael Crawford) observes as he explains how he led his
•3rd Troop, 4th Musketeers and

won the war while on assignment
to build a cricket pitch behind
enemy lines in North Africa. But
it is of course-horribly, slopily,
grotesquely funny. It is funny
when the gangling, gung-ho-young
lieutenant exults jubilantly over
"Our first real victory!" because
his men have shot down a British
plane. "One of our own of course
but still our first real victory." It is
funny when a woman rushes up
from nowhere, bending over a
bleeding body with the rapt concern of a cockney Nightengale.
Both legs have been blown off.
"It hurts Flo," the twitching body
says. "Run them under the cold
tap, luv."
Caught With Pants Down
It is funny, not fun. "I die in
North Africa," one of the soldiers
explains to us in the beginning. We
smile. Then we know he means it.
Bang. With his pants down, hop-

1

ping away from the latrines.
"We're all going to die under funny names," and they do, one by
one, close up, twitching, very real,
very funny. And all without realizing their once consuming ambi
tion, to kill their lieutenant. So
that when John gets it between the
legs, it is really not so surprising
It is very, sadly, comically inevita-.
ble and he(like Paul in Remarque's
All Quiet On the Western Front)
looks rather relieved that the waiting is over.
But Lester's real accomplishment lies in his making the inevitable believable, making us feel
what we know. If his audience left
the theater marveling at the revelation that war was not funny but
absurd, not nice but sickening, he
would not be happy. He wants
them to vomit in the streets to remember their nausea the next time
they read a body count and the

Nine Diversified Johns Hopkins Students Discuss What's on Their Minds
By ELIA KATZ
Did you see the article in the
Johns Hopkins Journal wherein
nine diversified students (all from
the same fraternity)held forth on
three diversified question, and the
entire symposium was collected
under the fascinating headline:
"Yes Virginia, there are students
who don't protest"? On reading,
that was rather embarrassing,
don't you think? Embarrassing
that nine students, each so unique,
so singular and distinct from the
rest, could come up with nine absolutely identical answers to any
question put to them. After all
(one is forced to think) there,
around that dinner table was all
the diversity our little University
could ever hope to muster — a
White Anglo Saxon Protestant was
there, along with a person of Italian dissent, a person of Jewish
dissent and a person of colored
dissent. And there was the son of
the famous French sculptor, August Rodin, and there was the
grandson of a famous poet (I forget who) and it seems that this
prestigious assemblage could have
produced something a little classier
than those bread-thoughts presented,in the Journal.
Listen to this question: "If you
were suddenly to find yourself in
a position of power, what would
you do with it?" Does it not shame
you that when nine Hopkins boys
were asked that question each one
said that he would make this a better world in which to live? There
is no conceivable way they could
have demonstrated less intelligence
or comprehension of the way
things are than by saying a thing
like that.
("I'd make a happy, teeny bopper world. I'd like to see poverty
ended and I would use Lyndon
Johnson—like programs all day
long. I think they're great.")
A better world in which to live.

them even suggested he'd "form a
uniform program to promote understanding of people's goals," and
other things to that effect. Answers like that, buddy,come from
Miss America contestants when
they yuk it up with Bert Parks,
not topnotch whiz kids in the political sciences. I mean nobody -not a single one — had a viable,
specific plan for the utilization of
all that power. Nobody said, for
instance, that they would take all
the money away from the rich
people and give it to the poor people. Nobody said they would stop
the war or build highways or pass

Itioppers Fear Biting
By JAMES BENNETT
It's the kiddie matinee and
there's hardly room to breathe—
ten thousand nose-sniffling tenyear-olds in from the cold for
another Saturday afternoon funfest. But they're a tempermental
lot. Last week's Lust Bat Meets
She Wolf's Sister-in-Law didn't hit
it off with them. The horror shows
have lost their punch. The old
spines aren't tingling like they use
to. Sure they get a kick out of
monster movies. But year in, year
out, the same tired plot. Hollywood is stunting their growth.
They've had it up to their ears.
The M & M's have stopped melting
in their hands. What fun is it
anymore? The kids want it straight
and they want it hard. Tell it
like it is, MGM.
• Enter Roman Polanski (Knife
in the Water) and The Fearless
Vampire Killers.
It's midnight. Three feet of
snow on the ground. A rundown
traveler's lodge far back in the
wilds of Transylvania. A lovely
young barmaid sleeps peacefully
in her small attic room. Suddenly
at the window. A dark figure.
He enters. Count Dracula! Our
unsuspecting lass awakes.She gasps
instinctively pulling the covers up
over her. My what a great big
bountiful body you have, my dear,
thinks the vampire. Snickering evilly he nears, a bloodsucking gleam
in his eyes. Helpless innocence
about to be ravished. What can
she do? Ten thousand kids inhale
as one, inching up to the edge of
their seats. If only we could
stop him. But no. We are powerless. The child's fate is sealed. She
—mu51- accvt her doom with a stout
heart. The tension has been too
much. A frenzied five year old
snaps and comes barreling down
the theatre aisle, arms flailing
"The cross," he screams hysterically, "the cross, the cross." Of
course! The crucifix. Above her
bed table. Now we all see it and
must add our own cries of warn-

ing. The theatre erupts in a welter
of uncontrolled shrieking. Finally
the camera spies it. There's hope.
The vampire steps closer. "The
crucifix!" we thunder. And ten
thousand tiny forefingers point at
the Panavision screen. Our call is
heard. The barmaid reaches back
removing our Blessed Saviour from
the wall. The vampire lunges forward.She thrusts the cross trimphantly in his face. "Sic semper
tyrannis!" we cry and drop back
into our seats relieved of a terrible
strain. She's saved. No self-respecting vampire is about to contend
with the most sacred relic of the
church. Or so we would have
thought. This one is utterly undaunted. He licks his lips mischievously, ogling the soon-to-beplundered barmaid. "Oh, baby,"
he says with a Yiddish accent,
"have you got the wrong vampire."
The theatre explodes in laughter.
And the poor barmaid is out for
the count.
Director Polanski has given us
in The Fearless Vampire Killers a
real satiric treat. The kids get their
blood and gore while the sophisticates are teased silly with
outrageous puns and Sharon Tate.
Mr. Polanski himself assumes a
starring role as the timid young
assistant of Jack McGowan who,
as the typical frizzy-haired professor, is wickedly funny. After handling the devastatingly beautiful
Catherine Deneuve in Repulsion,
Polanski now offers us Miss Tate
whose part in Vampires consists
of stepping from one hot bath into
another. She manages, however,
to pull it off quite well. And that
voice. That lip-twitching, lisping
Recited by her, even the Gettysburg Address would reek with
sexual innuendo. One gets giddy
just thinking about it. Polanski's
comic scenes and colorful camera
technique are reminiscent of Richardson's Tom Jones. The special
effects and musical score are truly
ghoulish delights.

Laurence and Kwai
It is with less conventional
means however, that Lester makes
his mark. Prominent among them
is his mocking of other World War
II movies and his brilliant interweaving of newsreel footage of the
war. The first technique represents
most explicitly Lester's quarrel
with the "legacy of fiction" which
has grown up around this war and
all of them, the stupid celebration
of what can only be mourned.
When the trucks roll across the desert we hear the same theme music
of Lawrence of Arabia that echoed
in our ears at Oscar time. When the
British misfits encounter a large
German encampment and are
hopelessly outnumbered, they
simply march single file into the
middle of the camp, resolutely
whistling the theme song from

The Bridge on the River Kwai,
whereupon the terrified Germans
throw up their hands in impotent
astonishment and defeat.
The use of newsreels is nothing
Occasionally
short of brilliant.
throughout the film a still picture
flashes on the screen, a comicbook illustration of a famous battle. Follows the monochrome (sepia or green or brown) newsreel
of such comic scenes as Dunkirk
with lightning flashbacks to the
actors on the same beach dying
the same way, as the real and long
dead soldiers in the newsreels. In
this act of conscious art-making,
soldier and actor, past and fiction
merge magnificiently. If Lester's
film is funny, so is Dunkirk. If
Dunkirk was tragic, so is Lester's
film. Distinctions are blurred, the
gap is bridged. At the end of each
newsreel sequence, one man, more
of the British patrol has died. In a
final coup, Lester fills his place
with a new (or old or eternal) man,
painted from head to toe the color
of the newsreel from which he has
emerged. Art and reality are one.
Lennon For Anti-hero
Yet for all its brilliance, the
film does not, finally, succeed.
Lester has been overly ambitious.
In attempting to capture the tragicomic essence of war, he has gone
a bit overboard from both ends.
Much of the comedy is labored,
overdone,familiar! Generals trade
bubble gum cards and recruits
march in the wrong direction. On
the other hand, fatalism saturates
everything; Lester deals nothing
but spades. If a film like Lawrence

an anti-hero. For every Odysseus,
glorying in the trail by Cyclops,
there must be an Aeneas, who
would rather turn and run. Perhaps John Lennon was his man,
but he did not exploit him, and
this is the film's most significant
failure. Catch-22 succeeds where
"How I Won the War" does not
because of a certain young man
named Yossarian.
There are other minor defects.
There is the film's general lack of
coherence, more regrettable than
"arty". There is Lester's dual purpose, his attack not only upon war
but upon the myths of war, which
dilutes his thrust against both.
Occasionally too, his out slips into
dogmatism; he begins to preach.
No Place for Wagnet
But none of these flaws can obscure the magnitude of Lester's accomplishment, the fold step he
has taken. These soldiers became
as real to us as the soldiers that
died in Dunkirk. They are plowed
down one by one,as we know that
real soldiers are, but somehow
never believe it. We do know.
They do not die the way hundreds
of Robert Mitchums and John
Waynes have in Cinemascope, but
the messy way John Lennon does.
We knew it of course, but we
never really believed it. We do now.
All of this because Lester has
approached the art of the film in a
new way, the way of the intellect,
the way of consciousness, the way
of symbols. Like Fellini in Juliet
of the Spirits, like Picasso when
he discovered the angles that made
up a cube, Lester is exploring a
kind of art that reaches the heart
by starting at the mind. It has not
yet made it all the way,somebody
will, perhaps even soon.

By SETH FELDMAN
There were once those of us
who fought the odious idea that
the species of fauna attending
JHU was any more apathetic than
the average collection of carefree
youth. We pointed with pride at
the indisputable fact that 18% of
the undergraduate body returned
their Course Guide questionairea
and that the vast majority of these
were filled in with a modest degree
of care and interest. Who could
talk of lack of student participation at Hopkins when confronted
with this evidence? Who could
dare to slur our fair institution
with names like Johns Apathy and
The Hell With U.? Here was documented proof that 18% of the
members of the undergraduate
body were willing to spend up to
10 minutes a piece contributing to
the only objective analysis of their
academic environment. Based on
this figure, one can, with subtle
and precise mathematical calculation, conclude that at least
37.6875% of the undergraduate
body will be interested enough to
show up for graduation and that
48.1973% actually have strong
feelings as to whether they live or
die. Why that's almost a majority!
But now there is no longer any
defense against these charges of
apathy.The Hopkins student body
has performed the ultimate apathetic atrocity. We, the student body
of this great university, totally
ignored the President of the United
States.
Huh? What? Why? How? There
is no use in trying to deny the
crime. Johnson's visit was adequately publicized in a clearly labled News-Letter campus note("LBJ
to Speak Here"—December 15 issue.) The note went on to give
the specifics of the event, but,
incredible as it may seem, almost
nobody came.
Steve Shriver, famed Dow
Chemical picket, was there. Steve
arrived at 3 a.m. and spent the
night on the Shriver Hall steps
braving the first Antarctic blizzard
ever recorded in the Baltimore
area. At noon, when the first of
the 48 motorcycles roared up to
Shriver Hall, Steve stood up to
confront the President. At 12:10,
a black bullet-proof limosine pulled up and the assembled musicians
began to play "Hail to the Chief".

Antarctic Storm Decimates Penguins
This year's winter appears to be
a rough one all over the world. A
report has just come in from Johns
Hopkins Professor William Sladen
which indicates that the Emperor
penguin rookery at Cape Croizier,
Antarctica, has been devastated by
a furious storm over the past
winter.
Although it is the summer now
in Antarctica, Dr. Sladen's party
has only recently been able to
reach the famous rookery to witness the destruction. Although
about 500 adult penguins are still
alive, Dr. Sladen reported that all
the chicks and unhatched eggs
were smashed or blown into the
sea
The Emperor penguin stands
three feet high and may weigh
ninety pounds. The females, however, lay only a single egg each,
and it is feared that one or two
more severe winters may endanger
the species. The National Science
Foundation has taken steps to
protect the penguins.
Dr. Sladen, an ex-physician, is
considered one of the world's leading penguin authorities and has

spent the last two months in field
work studying the breeding sites
of birds. Altogether he has spent
over seven years in Antarctica. Dr.
Sladen is particularly interested in
the behaviorial aspects of the extremely sociable penguin, for he
believes that valuable insights into
human relationships may be
gained.
The professor is no stranger to
violent storms. Recently the party
was caught in a particularly severe
one near another rookery. He gave
the following account of that
storm:
"The wind gauge was destroyed
in the early part of the storm after
it had been recording gusts of well
over 100 miles an hour. Many
colonies were abandoned during
the height of the storm and all
eggs blew away, the birds seeking
shelter in dips or behind large
rocks.
"From time to time . . . they
would struggle back to their sites
and sometimes were . . . picked up
by the wind and hurled head-overheels, with flippers and legs spread,
down the slope . . . like leaves
scattered in a storm."

Here come the new

The Blue Lagoon
Two years ago the Hopkins
swimming team consisted of six
swimmers and two divers. Together
they compiled a 1-5 record, struggled to fill all the events and beat
F&M in the seasons' finale only
because the Diplomats had less
swimmers than the Jays. Only
three members of that unknown
crew remained, but the progress
Hopkins has made is, if anything,
in inverse relation to the number
of swimmers.
Do It Yourself
The credit for the improvement
must be given to the swimmers. In
a sport where teamwork is a minimal requirement, each individual
member must assume a responsibility to drive himself to the utmost. Not everyone can; and this
may explain the small size of this
year's varsity (there are twelve
swimmers and two divers). As yet
however, there remain few top
swimmers at Hopkins. Aside from
Chernick and Weikel, and diver
Wilson who win consistently, the
Jays will never be able to handle
Yale, USC,Stanford,or even Bucknell. On a nation-wide scale Hopkins swimming is at best mediocre; but there is no reason why it
has to remain that way.
Coaching is Key Factor
The answer to mediocrity is
coaching. Since one must be driven
to produce top times, the necessity
for a domineering coach is paramount. Leo Durocher said, "Nice
guys finish last", and thus far the
swimming team has proven his
point. What the Jays have acomplished this year has been almost
in spite of, not because of, the
coaching and entire administrative
setup for the swimming team. The
pool has been closed for days for
repairs. Training meals before away
have failed to materialize, and the

coach himself has often missed
practice of left early. The Santa
Clara swim club has proven that
the only way to develop top swimmers is to swim, — miles and miles.
Thus far, the Jays have been lucky
to log one mile a day. Stamina and
conditioning the key elements of
good swimmers have not been developed, and the Jays will remain
mediocre until they are.
Swimmers will Work
It is a shame too, because good
tough workouts will produce the
physchological as well as thephysical lift needed for victory. The
Jays last relay loss to defending
MAC champ Dickinson, — exemplifies this point. The toughness
ingrained into championship teams
in any sport begins with tough,
hard-nosed coaching. The team
cannot drive itself. Only a top
flight coach will be able to develop
a Hopkins swimming team comparable to the quality of the pool
it swims in.
The freshman swimming team
is in the process of developing.
Probably the strongest squad
Hopkins has had, the Baby Jays
have been greatly strenghtened by
the addition of Mike O'Donnell
whose breaststroke times have
been the best ever recorded by a
Hopkins swimmer.
After nipping Bainbridge Prep
in their season's opener the frosh
swamped both Gettysburg and
Southern High School before bowing to Delaware.
Nucleus Developed
If the purpose of a freshman
team is to develop candidates for
varsity positions, then the freshman are more than fulfilling their
obligations. Besides O'Donnell,
who gives the Jays their first legitimate breaststroker, they will add
at least one man in every event on
the card.

SNCC Seeki g Control
Of City Scboo! System
By STEVE SHRIVER
The first major goal of the newly-established Baltimore SNCC will
be the control of the public school
system by the black people of
Baltimore.
"Black children make up 70
per cent of the school population
of Baltimore," said Baltimore Field
Secretary Robert Moore,"but they
have always gotten the rotten end
of the deal. The whites of this city
have completely forfeited any right
to make decisions in this area."
SNCC has joined a coalition of
eight other Human Rights groups,
among them CORE, U-JOIN and
the Interdenominational Ministerial Alliance, to press the attack on
the school system. The groups immediate demands are the installation of six "Afro-Americans" on
the Baltimore School Board and
the appointment of a black Superintendent of Schools. The group
has recommended John Hopkins,
former assistant to the late School
Superintendent Lawrence Paquin
who is in charge of the Community School Program, for the
position.
Coalition
SNCC has presented the coalition with its three-point program.
It calls for instruction in AfroAmerican History and Swahili, and
for the control of local schools by
the neighborhood..
"Black people are in a better
position to understand the needs
of black children than are white
people," said Mr. Moore. He also
indicated that the "general feeling"
of the coalition was favorable to
.the SNCC program.
In a corollary program, Mr.
Moore said that SNCC would work
to establish Black Student Unions
in the Junior and Senior High
Schools. He said that high school
students had been found to be
"very aware of what was happening." He said that nine high school
rebellions had taken place this fall.
He also indicated that the Unions
would include programs of Black
Draft Resistance.
Assist Blacks
Moore said that SNCC would
encourage and assist students at
black colleges to form student

Crime Reporter

unions tO fight for student-faculty
control and to bring the "culture
and heritage of the Afro- American
to the campus." In line with this,
he said SNCC would seek to create
ties between these colleges potential sources of leadership and the
black community.
"Despite their responsibility to
relate to it," he added,"most students look down on the black community." He charged that college
administrations fostered this outlook while attempting to serve
White America.
Mr. Moore called on black students at Hopkins to form a Black
Student Union, and also stated
that the SNCC office would welcome student assistance as well as
offer help to sympathetic groups.
SNCC is sharing its office with
U-JOIN and the Mothers Rescuers
from Poverty, a welfare group at
432 East North Avenue.The office

JOURNAL JOLTED
To the Editors:
Hopkins Alumni Journal
Your recent article about Hopkins undergraduates titled "Yes,
Virginia, There Are Students Who
Don't Protest" tells a great deal
about the campus, and about the
sort of school Hopkins is, It very
clearly points out the isolation of
the University and of its students.
For the "nine diversified Johns
Hopkins students" interviewed
"foreign policy, Vietnam and the
draft" play a very unimportant
part in life. It's very nice not to
have to worry about things like
that. It's nice to have attended a
private school, and even nicer to
have attended "private schools in
Paris and New England." It's nice
to be "surrounded by people like'
me. We're not worried about the
draft because we'll probably
never be drafted. Most of us go
to graduate school." It's nice to
be able to worry about not becoming "a fat and happy businessman". And it's nice to know
that "since we're living in a society of consumer idiots" that
"there are enough of them to
support a few idiots like me."
It's also nice to have enough
money to come to Hopkins.
What's the Journal getting at?
Are these nine randomly picked
students? One of them is Black.
Does that mean that one of every
nine undergraduates is Black? or
one of every twenty? or thirty?
What relation should a university
have to the society that supports
it? What is Hopkins doing to
benefit that society? Should a
university function as a sanctuary
from the draft, as a protection

Correspondence

any real involvement with problems outside the campus?
These are very real problems.
Hopkins must learn that it does
have a role outside the boundaries
of Homewood. We must learn
that the Black slum, the poor,
and Vietnam are very much our
problems. The Applied Physics
designs missile systems. The Hospital does research into biological
warfare. Hopkins makes no more
than token moves to admit Black
undergraduates. Until Hopkins
can recognize its responsibilities
she can expect no more than the
complacency and isolation the
students you have interviewed
have shown.
Sincerely,
Michael D. Ornstein
Department of
Social Relations

To the Editors:
One would like to think that
the four points from the draft bill
of rights quoted in last Friday's
News-Letter are perhaps not typical of the whole document, although I would not hold out much
hope. Since the bill will undoubtedly be notable more for what it
does not contain than for what it
does, it is perhaps a bit early to
criticize it. However, even .in the
excerpt that appearedin the NewsLetter there are tiems that are not
only useless but positively harmful.
Consider, for example, Point
Four, which concerns the NewsLetter directly: "No student publication shall be subjected to any
form of censorship so long as it

remains within the limits of acceptable community standards"? Would thi!
mean a ban on four-letter words?
Most members of the university
community use four-letter words
in their speech. Would an article
by a member of the NLFSV bc
permitted to appear? Many Hopkins students support a policy
that says that members of the
NLFSV should be killed. The
people who are to define "acceptable community standards"
are faced with a difficult task
indeed.

difficulty of defining these standards are the insidious implications of even trying. The editors
of the News-Letter are entrusted
with an important job. They
should also be trusted to use their

being one-sided. Keeping student

funds that go to the student paper are money well-spent is a

COMPUTER CONFUSION
To the Editors:
In reply to Mr. Sakowich's satire in last week's News-Letter, I
can only say that he has missed
the entire significance of the university's gesture. The administration finally does something nice
for its students and what thanks
do they receive? Sarcasm! I am
not saying that there aren't way
to improve this program, but this
is certainly a start. If the administration thinks that all of the
students think the way you do,
they could justifiably terminate
the program.
What you are missing is that
20 — 25% of the students 911this
campus know how to program a
computer, and for them computer time is a very valuable and
unobtainable commodity. And,

for those who lack such training,
it takes only $1.00 to purchase
a manual for BASIC in the bookstore, and a couple of hours of
study can produce results. There
is nothing mystical or magical
about computer programming,
and it's simpler than any foreign
language. .
What freshman chemistry student wouldn't like to have a
computer do his homework for
him? Access to a computer can
also reduce the drudgery of repeated calculations for physics
labs, and computer programming
is an integral part of many advanced sciences. Since about 2/3
of Hopkins students are science
majors, there may be far more
people who are interested in this
program than you indicate.
I can understand an English
major's sarcasm at such a program, but I personally know
several graduate students in such
fields as Semitics, ancient languages, and Education who are
programming the major part of
their Masters or Doctoral theses.
Computer programming is invading other areas as well, for
example teaching, moviemaking,
and even poetry and music. Computers are already capable of
beating beginners at such games
as chess, checkers and bridge.
If, however, you, and the
many others like you, feel that
the computer is alien to you and
has no place in your lives except
in D-level of the library, please
drop your cards in box 2129 and
they will be put to better use
than making paper airplanes or
papering the walls.
Warren Levy '70

The Yearning Years
In retrospect, a college "education" must seem a cruel paradox. If
we have learned anything from four years of lectures, seminars,
exams and papers it is the harsh realization of how much remains
unlearned. A semester of Dante teaches us how inadequate one semester can be. We learn enough to become curious, enough to become
interested, but in the last analysis, not nearly enough. College teases
us but we can't get no satisfaction. It takes us half way there, if that
far.
The pressure to specialize pours salt on the wound. It is as strong
at Hopkins as anywhere, perhaps stronger. The pre-med, with Mitochondria and adenosine triphosphate burdening his mind, has only
vague recollections of Homer and Hegel.The history major associates
chemistry with lysergic acid and spends his waking hours absorbed in
the revisionist theories of the revisionist, who revised the revisionist
interpretation of the origins of the Civil War. The Hopkins student
may gain some expertise in a narrow field of study while in other
disciplines he remains functionally illiterate.
In this sense, the University may be at fault. We are always told
about the virtues of our liberal academic philosophy, struck from
the mold of German universities. Hopkins is, in fact, a ;staunch defender of academic freedom and it is indeed a more desirable educational philosophy than that practiced by a Princeton or Chicago
where rigidity is the by-word. The freedom to structure one's education almost free of insipid requirements should not be taken lightly.
The reality of this liberal philosophy, however, has not created the
"Renaissance man" at Hopkins nor has it created anything more
than an incipient specialist.
The fault does not, however,lie with Lincoln Gordon,or his nine
predecessors,or the faculty,or the student. The roots of the problem
must be traced back to the day one enters public school for the first
time. The tragedy of the Hopkins student is that the liberal, progressive philosophy of his college does not jive with the rigid conservatism that governs the first twelve years of his education. In essence,
a liberal philosophy of higher education assumes that the individual
possesses a high degree of technical knowledge and that a college
should stress development of the analytical powers of reasoning. This
is a false assumption since the products of the public school system
are ill-prepared to cope with anything more provocative than Introductory Chemistry or History.
Consequently, Hopkins and other surveyors of academic freedom
must keep a stiff upper lip and give their entering students cram
courses in the fundamentals of Biology and Sociology. It is not until the third or fourth year that the student is asked to use his mind
and manipulate ideas, but by that time his intellectual curiosity is
worn thin by chemical formulas and historical dates.
The blame, as we said, lies squarely with the American system of
public education. Numerous attempts have been made to reform
"the system" but bureaucratization has rendered them futile. Recently, a committee chaired by McGeorge Bundy of the Ford
Thundation suggested to Mayor Lindsay of New York a sweeping
decentralization of that city's school system. The committee's report
proposed the creation of 30 to 60 largely autonomous school districts with each district run by a local school board. These local
school boards would have the power to hire and fire superintendants
and teachers,determine curricula and make decisions on tenure. As a
a result, the Board of Education would be restricted to the role of an
overseer. But the Bundy Report and any other plan for school decentralization is destined to fail unless basic changes are made in the
classroom.
Psychologists have been saying for years that the youngster is
capable of a much higher level of reasoning and understanding than
both his teachers and parents give him credit. The absudity of a college student clutching a Spanish elements book is a severe indictment of his elementary school years. While he was playing with
blocks and coloring pretty pictures, his mind was capable of a greater challenge-only the challenge never came.
This process of intellectual retardation leads to the great myths
that students acquire in high school. The industrial revolution is
glorified while some of its more iunfortunate creations are totally
ignored. Wars are exciting and colorful, not brutal and unbearable.
There have been some energetic people who tried to fight the
system, but they,like all the utopians before them, suffered ignominious defeat. Jonathan Kozol was kicked out of a Boston school
for reading a Langston Hughes poem to his class and Herbert Kohl's
sixth grade class in Harlem was forced to publish secretly a newspaper which expressed the fears and horrors of the ghetto. The system
had driven them underground.
The system is bureaucratic, insensitive,rigid and worst of all - the
destroyer of people's minds. It is, therefore, the unwanted duty of
institutions like Hopkins to reclaim, and regenerate the once promising intellects of its students. In this process, the tenets of academic freedom are necessarily neglected. This is indeed tragic but
Hopkins will be forced to turn out unsatisfactory products as long
as she is faced with the task of revitalizing the minds of her students.
The cruel paradox of college education will persist until the public
school system with the help of progressive universities turns'inward
and destroys those structures that contribute so heavily to the intellectual retardation of the student.

Lester: Gut Coarse

By MICHAEL G. MICHAELSON
Quietly,suddenly perhaps, with
resignation, John Lennon sits
down in the high thick grass. His
brown eyes open wide and innocent, his jaw drops, he seems tired,
sad,even a little amused. His hands
look a bit greenish, clasped there
over the red gushing mass of blood
that had once been his groin.
"You didn't expect this," he asks
the audience in a bored monotone,
"did you?"
Only we did. Of course we did.
Not because we have seen all the
reviews of How I Won the War
(which of course we have) not because we have seen the Beatle's
battered, bloody body splashed
on the cover of the October Ramparts (which of course we have)
but because director Richard Lester makes us expect it and does
even more. When it does happen,
he makes us believe it too.
Anti-Film Flick
Lester's film is about war and
war stories (war movies, war heroes, war villians). The dualism of
his subject is a product of Lester's
conviction not that war and the
celebration of war are the same,
but that just such a false identity
has been so easy and so comfortable to assume, so dishonest and so
simply, morally wrong. Lester is
Out to crush the myths,"the legacy" as he told an interviewer,"of
twenty years of fiction," and expose the "implausible, illogical,
secret and steel unreality," that is
the final (and paradoxical and
cruel) reality of war.
"It's not very funny, you
know," freckle-faced Lieutenant
Goodbody(Michael Crawford) observes as he explains how he led his
•3rd Troop, 4th Musketeers and

won the war while on assignment
to build a cricket pitch behind
enemy lines in North Africa. But
it is of course-horribly, slopily,
grotesquely funny. It is funny
when the gangling, gung-ho-young
lieutenant exults jubilantly over
"Our first real victory!" because
his men have shot down a British
plane. "One of our own of course
but still our first real victory." It is
funny when a woman rushes up
from nowhere, bending over a
bleeding body with the rapt concern of a cockney Nightengale.
Both legs have been blown off.
"It hurts Flo," the twitching body
says. "Run them under the cold
tap, luv."
Caught With Pants Down
It is funny, not fun. "I die in
North Africa," one of the soldiers
explains to us in the beginning. We
smile. Then we know he means it.
Bang. With his pants down, hop-

1

ping away from the latrines.
"We're all going to die under funny names," and they do, one by
one, close up, twitching, very real,
very funny. And all without realizing their once consuming ambi
tion, to kill their lieutenant. So
that when John gets it between the
legs, it is really not so surprising
It is very, sadly, comically inevita-.
ble and he(like Paul in Remarque's
All Quiet On the Western Front)
looks rather relieved that the waiting is over.
But Lester's real accomplishment lies in his making the inevitable believable, making us feel
what we know. If his audience left
the theater marveling at the revelation that war was not funny but
absurd, not nice but sickening, he
would not be happy. He wants
them to vomit in the streets to remember their nausea the next time
they read a body count and the

YES, VIRGINIA, THERE ARE STUDENTS WHO.DON'T PROTEST
Nine Diversified Johns Hopkins Students Discuss What's on Their Minds
By ELIA KATZ
Did you see the article in the
Johns Hopkins Journal wherein
nine diversified students (all from
the same fraternity)held forth on
three diversified question, and the
entire symposium was collected
under the fascinating headline:
"Yes Virginia, there are students
who don't protest"? On reading,
that was rather embarrassing,
don't you think? Embarrassing
that nine students, each so unique,
so singular and distinct from the
rest, could come up with nine absolutely identical answers to any
question put to them. After all
(one is forced to think) there,
around that dinner table was all
the diversity our little University
could ever hope to muster — a
White Anglo Saxon Protestant was
there, along with a person of Italian dissent, a person of Jewish
dissent and a person of colored
dissent. And there was the son of
the famous French sculptor, August Rodin, and there was the
grandson of a famous poet (I forget who) and it seems that this
prestigious assemblage could have
produced something a little classier
than those bread-thoughts presented,in the Journal.
Listen to this question: "If you
were suddenly to find yourself in
a position of power, what would
you do with it?" Does it not shame
you that when nine Hopkins boys
were asked that question each one
said that he would make this a better world in which to live? There
is no conceivable way they could
have demonstrated less intelligence
or comprehension of the way
things are than by saying a thing
like that.
("I'd make a happy, teeny bopper world. I'd like to see poverty
ended and I would use Lyndon
Johnson—like programs all day
long. I think they're great.")
A better world in which to live.
What could that mean? One of
them even suggested he'd "form a
uniform program to promote understanding of people's goals," and
other things to that effect. Answers like that, buddy,come from
Miss America contestants when
they yuk it up with Bert Parks,
not topnotch whiz kids in the political sciences. I mean nobody -not a single one — had a viable,
specific plan for the utilization of
all that power. Nobody said, for
instance, that they would take all
the money away from the rich
people and give it to the poor people. Nobody said they would stop
the war or build highways or pass
gun legislation ("It's easy to debate issues, but problems can't be

middle"
debated.")or effect free telephone
service or kill the Jews or force
little girls to give them pleasure.
Nothing! Just better. A better
world in. which to live. That's not
using the old bean when that's as
far as your thinking goes. That's
being a little fool, when you talk
like that.
But as thoughtless as the fellas
were in answering the big power
question, they outdid themselves
when it came to: "If you worry,

worry about becoming a fat and

there are real worries we people
have, you know? Very important
worries, all of them closer to the
top of the head than that lousy
worry. Like drug addiction or
pimples. Or fights with your father, or bacteriological warfare.
The War.(I'm worried, Father. My
wife had a kid they put him onna
table and his head rolled alla way
t' the side like his neck was made
outa shavin' cream, Father. Now
she's gonna have another one an'I
don't want that to happen to him.
What am I gonna do?) Death,

breakage, wear and tear, loneliness. Worry about being a dull
conversationalist or being unable
to get it up, or being blind in one
eye. And if you happen to be Negro, your big worry might include
your Negroness. Real WORRIES,
fellas. There is certainly no sense
worrying about becoming middleclass, because when you are grown
up you will, like all middle-class
men, like your daddies before
you, be unaware that you are actually in the middle-class. You'll
think there is something more to
you, something that sets you
apart. You'll be wrong, but that's
not as important as it seems.
All in all, a very depressing (if. .
diversified) group of interlocutors,
(Then I would have no reason to
exist. I don't believe in an afterlife. Urrrppp.) to say all that pap
to the folks on the outside, you
are saying to yourself.
But wait! There are further
considerations!
The boys — the nine — did not
talk in the crumby way after all
(you knew it all the time). No, I
talked to a couple of them and
they said the Journal pretty thoroughly distorted the discussion
in which they participated. The article didn't, as they say, tell it like
it was. That's an interesting thing
to know about the Johns Hopkins
.Journal. Because it is one thing to
get nine boobs and transcribe the
recordings of their inner selves and
put it on your front page to please
the alumni,as it appeared they did.
That would be a shame on the.
student body, but what could you

names and faces of nine living

folks with cash and proclivities
toward donation.

American U.like we should not do
that.

that "Yes, Virginia, there are students who don't protest," head for
purposes of pleasing all the insurance men and industrial big boys
who graduated from Hopkins in
'38 or '51 - - that's a real insult.
(Looka this Marcia honey. The
whole countriesfulla commies and
democrats, but they keep their
noses clean at Hopkins. Send 'em

be nice if the Journal would avoid
business like this in the future and
concentrate on the accurate reportage of alumni deaths.

Itioppers Fear Biting
By JAMES BENNETT
It's the kiddie matinee and
there's hardly room to breathe—
ten thousand nose-sniffling tenyear-olds in from the cold for
another Saturday afternoon funfest. But they're a tempermental
lot. Last week's Lust Bat Meets
She Wolf's Sister-in-Law didn't hit
it off with them. The horror shows
have lost their punch. The old
spines aren't tingling like they use
to. Sure they get a kick out of
monster movies. But year in, year
out, the same tired plot. Hollywood is stunting their growth.
They've had it up to their ears.
The M & M's have stopped melting
in their hands. What fun is it
anymore? The kids want it straight
and they want it hard. Tell it
like it is, MGM.
• Enter Roman Polanski (Knife
in the Water) and The Fearless
Vampire Killers.
It's midnight. Three feet of
snow on the ground. A rundown
traveler's lodge far back in the
wilds of Transylvania. A lovely
young barmaid sleeps peacefully
in her small attic room. Suddenly
at the window. A dark figure.
He enters. Count Dracula! Our
unsuspecting lass awakes.She gasps
instinctively pulling the covers up
over her. My what a great big
bountiful body you have, my dear,
thinks the vampire. Snickering evilly he nears, a bloodsucking gleam
in his eyes. Helpless innocence
about to be ravished. What can
she do? Ten thousand kids inhale
as one, inching up to the edge of
their seats. If only we could
stop him. But no. We are powerless. The child's fate is sealed. She
—mu51- accvt her doom with a stout
heart. The tension has been too
much. A frenzied five year old
snaps and comes barreling down
the theatre aisle, arms flailing
"The cross," he screams hysterically, "the cross, the cross." Of
course! The crucifix. Above her
bed table. Now we all see it and
must add our own cries of warn-

ing. The theatre erupts in a welter
of uncontrolled shrieking. Finally
the camera spies it. There's hope.
The vampire steps closer. "The
crucifix!" we thunder. And ten
thousand tiny forefingers point at
the Panavision screen. Our call is
heard. The barmaid reaches back
removing our Blessed Saviour from
the wall. The vampire lunges forward.She thrusts the cross trimphantly in his face. "Sic semper
tyrannis!" we cry and drop back
into our seats relieved of a terrible
strain. She's saved. No self-respecting vampire is about to contend
with the most sacred relic of the
church. Or so we would have
thought. This one is utterly undaunted. He licks his lips mischievously, ogling the soon-to-beplundered barmaid. "Oh, baby,"
he says with a Yiddish accent,
"have you got the wrong vampire."
The theatre explodes in laughter.
And the poor barmaid is out for
the count.
Director Polanski has given us
in The Fearless Vampire Killers a
real satiric treat. The kids get their
blood and gore while the sophisticates are teased silly with
outrageous puns and Sharon Tate.
Mr. Polanski himself assumes a
starring role as the timid young
assistant of Jack McGowan who,
as the typical frizzy-haired professor, is wickedly funny. After handling the devastatingly beautiful
Catherine Deneuve in Repulsion,
Polanski now offers us Miss Tate
whose part in Vampires consists
of stepping from one hot bath into
another. She manages, however,
to pull it off quite well. And that
voice. That lip-twitching, lisping
Recited by her, even the Gettysburg Address would reek with
sexual innuendo. One gets giddy
just thinking about it. Polanski's
comic scenes and colorful camera
technique are reminiscent of Richardson's Tom Jones. The special
effects and musical score are truly
ghoulish delights.

Then he assails the rationale of

Private Dimwitty(Lennon) muses,

morality. "Do you hate Jews."
Goodbody asks a German officer.
"Oh no! I love them dearly."

the humanity of the army: "I'm
not sorry about my men," Goodbody says, "they all had the same
faces . . . there it was for them, a
crusade . . . and they didn't respond."
Laurence and Kwai
It is with less conventional
means however, that Lester makes
his mark. Prominent among them
is his mocking of other World War
II movies and his brilliant interweaving of newsreel footage of the
war. The first technique represents
most explicitly Lester's quarrel
with the "legacy of fiction" which
has grown up around this war and
all of them, the stupid celebration
of what can only be mourned.
When the trucks roll across the desert we hear the same theme music
of Lawrence of Arabia that echoed
in our ears at Oscar time. When the
British misfits encounter a large
German encampment and are
hopelessly outnumbered, they
simply march single file into the
middle of the camp, resolutely
whistling the theme song from

The Bridge on the River Kwai,
whereupon the terrified Germans
throw up their hands in impotent
astonishment and defeat.
The use of newsreels is nothing
Occasionally
short of brilliant.
throughout the film a still picture
flashes on the screen, a comicbook illustration of a famous battle. Follows the monochrome (sepia or green or brown) newsreel
of such comic scenes as Dunkirk
with lightning flashbacks to the
actors on the same beach dying
the same way, as the real and long
dead soldiers in the newsreels. In
this act of conscious art-making,
soldier and actor, past and fiction
merge magnificiently. If Lester's
film is funny, so is Dunkirk. If
Dunkirk was tragic, so is Lester's
film. Distinctions are blurred, the
gap is bridged. At the end of each
newsreel sequence, one man, more
of the British patrol has died. In a
final coup, Lester fills his place
with a new (or old or eternal) man,
painted from head to toe the color
of the newsreel from which he has
emerged. Art and reality are one.
Lennon For Anti-hero
Yet for all its brilliance, the
film does not, finally, succeed.
Lester has been overly ambitious.
In attempting to capture the tragicomic essence of war, he has gone
a bit overboard from both ends.
Much of the comedy is labored,
overdone,familiar! Generals trade
bubble gum cards and recruits
march in the wrong direction. On
the other hand, fatalism saturates
everything; Lester deals nothing
but spades. If a film like Lawrence
of Arabia, which glorifies war,
needs a hero, then Lester should
have been able to see that what an
anti-war film like his needed was

By SETH FELDMAN
There were once those of us
who fought the odious idea that
the species of fauna attending
JHU was any more apathetic than
the average collection of carefree
youth. We pointed with pride at
the indisputable fact that 18% of
the undergraduate body returned
their Course Guide questionairea
and that the vast majority of these
were filled in with a modest degree
of care and interest. Who could
talk of lack of student participation at Hopkins when confronted
with this evidence? Who could
dare to slur our fair institution
with names like Johns Apathy and
The Hell With U.? Here was documented proof that 18% of the
members of the undergraduate
body were willing to spend up to
10 minutes a piece contributing to
the only objective analysis of their
academic environment. Based on
this figure, one can, with subtle
and precise mathematical calculation, conclude that at least
37.6875% of the undergraduate
body will be interested enough to
show up for graduation and that
48.1973% actually have strong
feelings as to whether they live or
die. Why that's almost a majority!
But now there is no longer any
defense against these charges of
apathy.The Hopkins student body
has performed the ultimate apathetic atrocity. We, the student body
of this great university, totally
ignored the President of the United
States.
Huh? What? Why? How? There
is no use in trying to deny the
crime. Johnson's visit was adequately publicized in a clearly labled News-Letter campus note("LBJ
to Speak Here"—December 15 issue.) The note went on to give
the specifics of the event, but,
incredible as it may seem, almost
nobody came.
Steve Shriver, famed Dow
Chemical picket, was there. Steve
arrived at 3 a.m. and spent the
night on the Shriver Hall steps
braving the first Antarctic blizzard
ever recorded in the Baltimore
area. At noon, when the first of
the 48 motorcycles roared up to
Shriver Hall, Steve stood up to
confront the President. At 12:10,
a black bullet-proof limosine pulled up and the assembled musicians
began to play "Hail to the Chief".

Antarctic Storm Decimates Penguins
This year's winter appears to be
a rough one all over the world. A
report has just come in from Johns
Hopkins Professor William Sladen
which indicates that the Emperor
penguin rookery at Cape Croizier,
Antarctica, has been devastated by
a furious storm over the past
winter.
Although it is the summer now
in Antarctica, Dr. Sladen's party
has only recently been able to
reach the famous rookery to witness the destruction. Although
about 500 adult penguins are still
alive, Dr. Sladen reported that all
the chicks and unhatched eggs
were smashed or blown into the
sea
The Emperor penguin stands
three feet high and may weigh
ninety pounds. The females, however, lay only a single egg each,
and it is feared that one or two
more severe winters may endanger
the species. The National Science
Foundation has taken steps to
protect the penguins.
Dr. Sladen, an ex-physician, is
considered one of the world's leading penguin authorities and has

spent the last two months in field
work studying the breeding sites
of birds. Altogether he has spent
over seven years in Antarctica. Dr.
Sladen is particularly interested in
the behaviorial aspects of the extremely sociable penguin, for he
believes that valuable insights into
human relationships may be
gained.
The professor is no stranger to
violent storms. Recently the party
was caught in a particularly severe
one near another rookery. He gave
the following account of that
storm:
"The wind gauge was destroyed
in the early part of the storm after
it had been recording gusts of well
over 100 miles an hour. Many
colonies were abandoned during
the height of the storm and all
eggs blew away, the birds seeking
shelter in dips or behind large
rocks.
"From time to time . . . they
would struggle back to their sites
and sometimes were . . . picked up
by the wind and hurled head-overheels, with flippers and legs spread,
down the slope . . . like leaves
scattered in a storm."

The Blue Lagoon
Two years ago the Hopkins
swimming team consisted of six
swimmers and two divers. Together
they compiled a 1-5 record, struggled to fill all the events and beat
F&M in the seasons' finale only
because the Diplomats had less
swimmers than the Jays. Only
three members of that unknown
crew remained, but the progress
Hopkins has made is, if anything,
in inverse relation to the number
of swimmers.
Do It Yourself
The credit for the improvement
must be given to the swimmers. In
a sport where teamwork is a minimal requirement, each individual
member must assume a responsibility to drive himself to the utmost. Not everyone can; and this
may explain the small size of this
year's varsity (there are twelve
swimmers and two divers). As yet
however, there remain few top
swimmers at Hopkins. Aside from
Chernick and Weikel, and diver
Wilson who win consistently, the
Jays will never be able to handle
Yale, USC,Stanford,or even Bucknell. On a nation-wide scale Hopkins swimming is at best mediocre; but there is no reason why it
has to remain that way.
Coaching is Key Factor
The answer to mediocrity is
coaching. Since one must be driven
to produce top times, the necessity
for a domineering coach is paramount. Leo Durocher said, "Nice
guys finish last", and thus far the
swimming team has proven his
point. What the Jays have acomplished this year has been almost
in spite of, not because of, the
coaching and entire administrative
setup for the swimming team. The
pool has been closed for days for
repairs. Training meals before away
have failed to materialize, and the

coach himself has often missed
practice of left early. The Santa
Clara swim club has proven that
the only way to develop top swimmers is to swim, — miles and miles.
Thus far, the Jays have been lucky
to log one mile a day. Stamina and
conditioning the key elements of
good swimmers have not been developed, and the Jays will remain
mediocre until they are.
Swimmers will Work
It is a shame too, because good
tough workouts will produce the
physchological as well as thephysical lift needed for victory. The
Jays last relay loss to defending
MAC champ Dickinson, — exemplifies this point. The toughness
ingrained into championship teams
in any sport begins with tough,
hard-nosed coaching. The team
cannot drive itself. Only a top
flight coach will be able to develop
a Hopkins swimming team comparable to the quality of the pool
it swims in.
The freshman swimming team
is in the process of developing.
Probably the strongest squad
Hopkins has had, the Baby Jays
have been greatly strenghtened by
the addition of Mike O'Donnell
whose breaststroke times have
been the best ever recorded by a
Hopkins swimmer.
After nipping Bainbridge Prep
in their season's opener the frosh
swamped both Gettysburg and
Southern High School before bowing to Delaware.
Nucleus Developed
If the purpose of a freshman
team is to develop candidates for
varsity positions, then the freshman are more than fulfilling their
obligations. Besides O'Donnell,
who gives the Jays their first legitimate breaststroker, they will add
at least one man in every event on
the card.

JIM CALL!
a driver, defensive player, and
quick offensive competitor. "One
of his outstanding abilities is in
drawing fouls from the opposition," stated the varsity mentor.
Calli opinioned that the trick in
obtaining foul calls is in opportunizing on the situation and "acting like you have been joulted."
He makes sure that the referees
and fans are aware that he has
(perhaps) been fouled.
This season's top defensive

player, Calli has regularly drawn
the opposition's best offensive
standout and shown superior talent
in tight man-on-man situations.
He has changed his shooting style
since his sophomore year td; a
more conventional jump shot
which has allowed him to compensate for his lack of height but
caused more sporatic shooting.
His speed also allowed him to better his driving ability last year.
A pre-med student from North
Vernon, Indiana, Jim, with an
academic average around 3.5, has
been accepted to the Johns Hopkins Medical School. His athletic
interests also include baseball, in
which he enters the starting lineup
in centerfield for the Jays.
"The quality of the teams play
has improved in the past two or
three games to a level which at
least equals that of the 1966
team," concluded Calli. He sees
the remainder of his varsity basketball career as one possessing a high
potential of success.

Baby Jays Team Effort
Demolishes Terrors
By RICH HOLLANDER
After dropping its first contest
of the season to the PMC frosh
last Thursday, the Baby Jays rebounded to beat the Western Maryland contingent,84-68
The Hopkins frosh controlled
the game handily and led at half
time, 43-38. Coach Gary Barrette
commented that his was the best
team effort of the season, as four
netmen finished in double figures.
The Jays effectively controlled the
offensive and defensive boards,
and they broke the game open
with high scoring in the second
half.
Coach Barrette replaced his
starters in the final minutes. Nevertheless, Sam Katz finished with 19
points, Norb Weidner had 18, Joe
Loveland posted 15, and Dave
Rebovich scored 13.
First Loss
Penn Military handed the frosh
their first setback last Thursday by
a 64-57 tally.
Dominating the .action until
late in the second half, the Jays
were able to capitalize on numerous Cadet turnovers. The frosh did
everything but put the ball in the
basket as they maneurvered adeptly ill the offensive zone. All the
breaks and ball control. were in
vain due to an abominable shooting percentage of 23 for 67. Remarkably, for the first 12 minutes
of the second half only guards
Rebovich and Katz attempted

•

shots from the field. Overall, Katz
hit for 17 and Rebovich for a
dozen, ten of which were in the
opening period.
PMC played two distinct games.
Before the intermission, they ran
a deliberate offense usually feeding forward John Zyla who was
high man with 21. A brief lapse in
the waning moments enabled J HU
to spurt ahead 29 to 26. The second half saw a rejuvenated Cadet
attack relying on the traditional
"run and gun." However, they
converted on a mere 25 out of 68
from the field. Hopkins maintained
a consistent margin of S to 8
points until 8 minutes before the
end of the game.
Rebounds Lost
The complete failure of the
Rosh to take defensive rebounds,
in the second half, spelled inevitable disaster. The Cadets scrambled
for third and fourth shots from
underneath. Meanwhile a frigid
Hopkins quintet had to force fifteen footers and rarely got a second shot.
So quickly did PMC take the
lead that the Jays never had enough
time to regain the momentum.
With four minutes remaining
Coach Barrette had his boys press,
but the deficit was already too
great.
